trans-unit.source: How to use table storage (C++) | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: How to use table storage (C++) | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use the table storage service in Azure. Samples are written in C++.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use the table storage service in Azure. Samples are written in C++.

trans-unit.source: This guide will show you how to perform common scenarios using the Azure Table Storage Service.
trans-unit.target: This guide will show you how to perform common scenarios using the Azure Table Storage Service.

trans-unit.source: The samples are written in C++ and use the <linkText>Azure Storage Client Library for C++</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: The samples are written in C++ and use the <linkText>Azure Storage Client Library for C++</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The scenarios covered include creating and deleting a table, as well as working with table entities.
trans-unit.target: The scenarios covered include creating and deleting a table, as well as working with table entities.

trans-unit.source: This guide targets the Azure Storage Client Library for C++ version 1.0.0 and above.
trans-unit.target: This guide targets the Azure Storage Client Library for C++ version 1.0.0 and above.

trans-unit.source: The recommended version is Storage Client Library 1.0.0, which is available via <linkText>NuGet</linkText><title></title> or <linkText>GitHub</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: The recommended version is Storage Client Library 1.0.0, which is available via <linkText>NuGet</linkText><title></title> or <linkText>GitHub</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: In this guide, you will use storage features which can be run within a C++ application.
trans-unit.target: In this guide, you will use storage features which can be run within a C++ application.

trans-unit.source: To do so, you will need to install the Azure Storage Client Library for C++ and create an Azure storage account in your Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: To do so, you will need to install the Azure Storage Client Library for C++ and create an Azure storage account in your Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: To install the Azure Storage Client Library for C++, you can use the following methods:
trans-unit.target: To install the Azure Storage Client Library for C++, you can use the following methods:

trans-unit.source: Linux: Follow the instructions given in the Azure Storage Client Library for C++ README page.
trans-unit.target: Linux: Follow the instructions given in the Azure Storage Client Library for C++ README page.

trans-unit.source: Windows: In Visual Studio, click Tools > NuGet Package Manager > Package Manager Console.
trans-unit.target: Windows: In Visual Studio, click Tools > NuGet Package Manager > Package Manager Console.

trans-unit.source: Type the following command into the NuGet Package Manager console and press ENTER.
trans-unit.target: Type the following command into the NuGet Package Manager console and press ENTER.

trans-unit.source: Add the following include statements to the top of the C++ file where you want to use the Azure storage APIs to access tables:
trans-unit.target: Add the following include statements to the top of the C++ file where you want to use the Azure storage APIs to access tables:

trans-unit.source: An Azure storage client uses a storage connection string to store endpoints and credentials for accessing data management services.
trans-unit.target: An Azure storage client uses a storage connection string to store endpoints and credentials for accessing data management services.

trans-unit.source: When running in a client application, you must provide the storage connection string in the following format, using the name of your storage account and the storage access key for the storage account listed in the Management Portal for the AccountName and AccountKey values.
trans-unit.target: When running in a client application, you must provide the storage connection string in the following format, using the name of your storage account and the storage access key for the storage account listed in the Management Portal for the AccountName and AccountKey values.

trans-unit.source: For information on storage accounts and access keys, see <linkText>About Azure Storage Accounts</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For information on storage accounts and access keys, see <linkText>About Azure Storage Accounts</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: This example shows how you can declare a static field to hold the connection string:
trans-unit.target: This example shows how you can declare a static field to hold the connection string:

trans-unit.source: To test your application in your local Windows computer, you can use the Microsoft Azure <linkText>storage emulator</linkText><title></title> that is installed with the <linkText>Azure SDK</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: To test your application in your local Windows computer, you can use the Microsoft Azure <linkText>storage emulator</linkText><title></title> that is installed with the <linkText>Azure SDK</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The storage emulator is a utility that simulates the Blob, Queue, and Table services available in Azure on your local development machine.
trans-unit.target: The storage emulator is a utility that simulates the Blob, Queue, and Table services available in Azure on your local development machine.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows how you can declare a static field to hold the connection string to your local storage emulator:
trans-unit.target: The following example shows how you can declare a static field to hold the connection string to your local storage emulator:

trans-unit.source: To start the Azure storage emulator, Select the Start button or press the Windows key.
trans-unit.target: To start the Azure storage emulator, Select the Start button or press the Windows key.

trans-unit.source: Begin typing Azure Storage Emulator, and select Microsoft Azure Storage Emulator from the list of applications.
trans-unit.target: Begin typing Azure Storage Emulator, and select Microsoft Azure Storage Emulator from the list of applications.

trans-unit.source: The following samples assume that you have used one of these two methods to get the storage connection string.
trans-unit.target: The following samples assume that you have used one of these two methods to get the storage connection string.

trans-unit.source: You can use the cloud_storage_account class to represent your Storage Account information.
trans-unit.target: You can use the cloud_storage_account class to represent your Storage Account information.

trans-unit.source: To retrieve your storage account information from the storage connection string, you can use the parse method.
trans-unit.target: To retrieve your storage account information from the storage connection string, you can use the parse method.

trans-unit.source: Next, get a reference to a cloud_table_client class as it allows you lets you get reference objects for tables and entities stored within the Table Storage Service.
trans-unit.target: Next, get a reference to a cloud_table_client class as it allows you lets you get reference objects for tables and entities stored within the Table Storage Service.

trans-unit.source: The following code creates a cloud_table_client object using the storage account object we retrieved above:
trans-unit.target: The following code creates a cloud_table_client object using the storage account object we retrieved above:

trans-unit.source: A cloud_table_client object lets you get reference objects for tables and entities.
trans-unit.target: A cloud_table_client object lets you get reference objects for tables and entities.

trans-unit.source: The following code creates a cloud_table_client object and uses it to create a new table.
trans-unit.target: The following code creates a cloud_table_client object and uses it to create a new table.

trans-unit.source: To add an entity to a table, create a new table_entity object and pass it to table_operation::insert_entity.
trans-unit.target: To add an entity to a table, create a new table_entity object and pass it to table_operation::insert_entity.

trans-unit.source: The following code uses the customer's first name as the row key and last name as the partition key.
trans-unit.target: The following code uses the customer's first name as the row key and last name as the partition key.

trans-unit.source: Together, an entity's partition and row key uniquely identify the entity in the table.
trans-unit.target: Together, an entity's partition and row key uniquely identify the entity in the table.

trans-unit.source: Entities with the same partition key can be queried faster than those with different partition keys, but using diverse partition keys allows for greater parallel operation scalability.
trans-unit.target: Entities with the same partition key can be queried faster than those with different partition keys, but using diverse partition keys allows for greater parallel operation scalability.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>Microsoft Azure Storage Performance and Scalability Checklist</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>Microsoft Azure Storage Performance and Scalability Checklist</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The following code creates a new instance of table_entity with some customer data to be stored.
trans-unit.target: The following code creates a new instance of table_entity with some customer data to be stored.

trans-unit.source: The code next calls table_operation::insert_entity to create a table_operation object to insert an entity into a table, and associates the new table entity with it.
trans-unit.target: The code next calls table_operation::insert_entity to create a table_operation object to insert an entity into a table, and associates the new table entity with it.

trans-unit.source: Finally, the code calls the execute method on the cloud_table object.
trans-unit.target: Finally, the code calls the execute method on the cloud_table object.

trans-unit.source: And the new table_operation sends a request to the storage service to insert the new customer entity into the "people" table.
trans-unit.target: And the new table_operation sends a request to the storage service to insert the new customer entity into the "people" table.

trans-unit.source: You can insert a batch of entities to the table service in one write operation.
trans-unit.target: You can insert a batch of entities to the table service in one write operation.

trans-unit.source: The following code creates a table_batch_operation object, then adds three insert operations to it.
trans-unit.target: The following code creates a table_batch_operation object, then adds three insert operations to it.

trans-unit.source: Each insert operation is added by creating a new entity object, setting its values, and then calling the insert method on the table_batch_operation object to associate the entity with a new insert operation.
trans-unit.target: Each insert operation is added by creating a new entity object, setting its values, and then calling the insert method on the table_batch_operation object to associate the entity with a new insert operation.

trans-unit.source: Then, cloud_table.execute is called to execute the operation.
trans-unit.target: Then, cloud_table.execute is called to execute the operation.

trans-unit.source: Some things to note on batch operations:
trans-unit.target: Some things to note on batch operations:

trans-unit.source: You can perform up to 100 insert, delete, merge, replace, insert or merge, and insert or replace operations in any combination in a single batch.
trans-unit.target: You can perform up to 100 insert, delete, merge, replace, insert or merge, and insert or replace operations in any combination in a single batch.

trans-unit.source: A batch operation can have a retrieve operation, if it is the only operation in the batch.
trans-unit.target: A batch operation can have a retrieve operation, if it is the only operation in the batch.

trans-unit.source: All entities in a single batch operation must have the same partition key.
trans-unit.target: All entities in a single batch operation must have the same partition key.

trans-unit.source: A batch operation is limited to a 4MB data payload.
trans-unit.target: A batch operation is limited to a 4MB data payload.

trans-unit.source: To query a table for all entities in a partition, use a table_query object.
trans-unit.target: To query a table for all entities in a partition, use a table_query object.

trans-unit.source: The following code example specifies a filter for entities where 'Smith' is the partition key.
trans-unit.target: The following code example specifies a filter for entities where 'Smith' is the partition key.

trans-unit.source: This example prints the fields of each entity in the query results to the console.
trans-unit.target: This example prints the fields of each entity in the query results to the console.

trans-unit.source: The query in this example brings all the entities that match the filter criteria.
trans-unit.target: The query in this example brings all the entities that match the filter criteria.

trans-unit.source: If you have large tables and need to download the table entities so often, we recommend that you store your data in Azure Storage Blobs instead.
trans-unit.target: If you have large tables and need to download the table entities so often, we recommend that you store your data in Azure Storage Blobs instead.

trans-unit.source: If you don't want to query all the entities in a partition, you can specify a range by combining the partition key filter with a row key filter.
trans-unit.target: If you don't want to query all the entities in a partition, you can specify a range by combining the partition key filter with a row key filter.

trans-unit.source: The following code example uses two filters to get all entities in partition 'Smith' where the row key (first name) starts with a letter earlier than 'E' in the alphabet and then prints the query results.
trans-unit.target: The following code example uses two filters to get all entities in partition 'Smith' where the row key (first name) starts with a letter earlier than 'E' in the alphabet and then prints the query results.

trans-unit.source: You can write a query to retrieve a single, specific entity.
trans-unit.target: You can write a query to retrieve a single, specific entity.

trans-unit.source: The following code uses a table_operation::retrive_entity to specify the customer 'Jeff Smith'.
trans-unit.target: The following code uses a table_operation::retrive_entity to specify the customer 'Jeff Smith'.

trans-unit.source: This method returns just one entity, rather than a collection, and the returned value is in table_result.
trans-unit.target: This method returns just one entity, rather than a collection, and the returned value is in table_result.

trans-unit.source: Specifying both partition and row keys in a query is the fastest way to retrieve a single entity from the Table service.
trans-unit.target: Specifying both partition and row keys in a query is the fastest way to retrieve a single entity from the Table service.

trans-unit.source: To replace an entity, retrieve it from the table service, modify the entity object, and then save the changes back to the table service.
trans-unit.target: To replace an entity, retrieve it from the table service, modify the entity object, and then save the changes back to the table service.

trans-unit.source: The following code changes an existing customer's phone number and email address.
trans-unit.target: The following code changes an existing customer's phone number and email address.

trans-unit.source: Instead of calling table_operation::insert_entity, this code uses table_operation::replace_entity.
trans-unit.target: Instead of calling table_operation::insert_entity, this code uses table_operation::replace_entity.

trans-unit.source: This causes the entity to be fully replaced on the server, unless the entity on the server has changed since it was retrieved, in which case the operation will fail.
trans-unit.target: This causes the entity to be fully replaced on the server, unless the entity on the server has changed since it was retrieved, in which case the operation will fail.

trans-unit.source: This failure is to prevent your application from inadvertently overwriting a change made between the retrieval and update by another component of your application.
trans-unit.target: This failure is to prevent your application from inadvertently overwriting a change made between the retrieval and update by another component of your application.

trans-unit.source: The proper handling of this failure is to retrieve the entity again, make your changes (if still valid), and then perform another table_operation::replace_entity operation.
trans-unit.target: The proper handling of this failure is to retrieve the entity again, make your changes (if still valid), and then perform another table_operation::replace_entity operation.

trans-unit.source: The next section will show you how to override this behavior.
trans-unit.target: The next section will show you how to override this behavior.

trans-unit.source: table_operation::replace_entity operations will fail if the entity has been changed since it was retrieved from the server.
trans-unit.target: table_operation::replace_entity operations will fail if the entity has been changed since it was retrieved from the server.

trans-unit.source: Furthermore, you must retrieve the entity from the server first in order for the table_operation::replace_entity to be successful.
trans-unit.target: Furthermore, you must retrieve the entity from the server first in order for the table_operation::replace_entity to be successful.

trans-unit.source: Sometimes, however, you don't know if the entity exists on the server and the current values stored in it are irrelevant - your update should overwrite them all.
trans-unit.target: Sometimes, however, you don't know if the entity exists on the server and the current values stored in it are irrelevant - your update should overwrite them all.

trans-unit.source: To accomplish this, you would use a table_operation::insert_or_replace_entity operation.
trans-unit.target: To accomplish this, you would use a table_operation::insert_or_replace_entity operation.

trans-unit.source: This operation inserts the entity if it doesn't exist, or replaces it if it does, regardless of when the last update was made.
trans-unit.target: This operation inserts the entity if it doesn't exist, or replaces it if it does, regardless of when the last update was made.

trans-unit.source: In the following code example, the customer entity for Jeff Smith is still retrieved, but it is then saved back to the server using table_operation::insert_or_replace_entity.
trans-unit.target: In the following code example, the customer entity for Jeff Smith is still retrieved, but it is then saved back to the server using table_operation::insert_or_replace_entity.

trans-unit.source: Any updates made to the entity between the retrieval and update operation will be overwritten.
trans-unit.target: Any updates made to the entity between the retrieval and update operation will be overwritten.

trans-unit.source: A query to a table can retrieve just a few properties from an entity.
trans-unit.target: A query to a table can retrieve just a few properties from an entity.

trans-unit.source: The query in the following code uses the table_query::set_select_columns method to return only the email addresses of entities in the table.
trans-unit.target: The query in the following code uses the table_query::set_select_columns method to return only the email addresses of entities in the table.

trans-unit.source: Note: Querying a few properties from an entity is more efficient operation than retrieving all properties.
trans-unit.target: Note: Querying a few properties from an entity is more efficient operation than retrieving all properties.

trans-unit.source: You can easily delete an entity after you have retrieved it.
trans-unit.target: You can easily delete an entity after you have retrieved it.

trans-unit.source: Once the entity is retrieved, call table_operation::delete_entity with the entity to delete.
trans-unit.target: Once the entity is retrieved, call table_operation::delete_entity with the entity to delete.

trans-unit.source: Then call execute on the cloud_table.execute method.
trans-unit.target: Then call execute on the cloud_table.execute method.

trans-unit.source: The following code retrieves and deletes an entity with partition key of "Smith" and row key of "Jeff".
trans-unit.target: The following code retrieves and deletes an entity with partition key of "Smith" and row key of "Jeff".

trans-unit.source: Finally, the following code example deletes a table from a storage account.
trans-unit.target: Finally, the following code example deletes a table from a storage account.

trans-unit.source: A table which has been deleted will be unavailable to be recreated for a period of time following the deletion.
trans-unit.target: A table which has been deleted will be unavailable to be recreated for a period of time following the deletion.

trans-unit.source: Now that you've learned the basics of table storage, follow these links to learn more about Azure Storage.
trans-unit.target: Now that you've learned the basics of table storage, follow these links to learn more about Azure Storage.
